## • <a name="connection_discover-data-asset">`connection discover-data-asset`</a>
Discover a data asset.

```sh
cpdctl connection discover-data-asset --data-asset-id DATA-ASSET-ID [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--limit LIMIT] [--offset OFFSET] [--fetch FETCH] [--detail=DETAIL] [--context CONTEXT] [--properties PROPERTIES] [--filters FILTERS] [--path PATH]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--context` (string)
:   Specify whether the asset is discovered for the purpose of reading (source) or writing (target). If not specified, source is used by default.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--data-asset-id` (string)
:   The ID of the data asset.

`--detail` (bool)
:   Specify whether to return additional asset-specific details. If not specified, these details are not returned.

    The default value is `false`.

`--fetch` (string)
:   Specify whether to return the asset's metadata, the asset's data, interaction properties, connection properties, or data source type. If not specified, metadata is used by default. This parameter only applies when requesting details about a data set. To specify multiple fetch values, use a comma-separated string, such as fetch=data,metadata,interaction,connection,datasource_type.

`--filters` (string)
:   A JSON object containing a set of properties to define filtering of the assets to be returned.

`--limit` (int64)
:   The limit of the number of items to return, for example limit=50. If not specified a default of 100 will be  used.

    The default value is `0`.

`--offset` (int64)
:   The 0-based index of the first result to return, for example, offset=200. If not specified, the default offset of 0 is used.

    The default value is `0`.

`--path` (string)
:   Path of the asset.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--properties` (string)
:   A JSON object containing a set of properties to configure aspects of the asset browsing.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl connection discover-data-asset \
    --data-asset-id exampleString \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id exampleString \
    --space-id exampleString \
    --limit 100 \
    --offset 0 \
    --fetch exampleString \
    --detail=true \
    --context source \
    --properties exampleString \
    --filters exampleString \
    --path exampleString
```
## • <a name="connection_get">`connection get`</a>
Gets details of a specific connection definition.

Connections created with shared credentials will return secrets such as database passwords and API keys in clear text. Such secrets are stored encrypted but will be decrypted by the API when retrieved by the caller in order to access the data source defined by the connection. Clear text credentials are allowed because it is understood that the caller has already been explicitly added as a collabaorator in the project or catalog in which the connection is stored and is thus implicitly permitted access to the credentials required to connect to a data source.

Connections created with personal credentials will only display clear text credentials to the same user who provided them.

```sh
cpdctl connection get {--connection-id CONNECTION-ID | --connection CONNECTION-NAME} [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--inject-token=INJECT-TOKEN] [--entity-product ENTITY-PRODUCT]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--connection` (string)
:   Connection name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--connection-id'.

`--connection-id` (string)
:   The ID of the connection. This option is mutually exclusive with '--connection'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--entity-product` (string)
:   Specify the product the data source type must support to be returned. The available products are 'catalog', 'cpd', 'datastage', 'dv', 'igc', 'mdi', 'ml' and 'studio'. If no entity.product is specified, no filtering is applied. To specify multiple products, use a comma-separated string, such as entity.product=catalog,studio.

`--inject-token` (bool)
:   Boolean indicator if cluster username and access token should be injected into connection properties. It has to be ensured that access token is not revealed unintentionally together with connection properties.

    The default value is `false`.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl connection get \
    --connection-id exampleString \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id exampleString \
    --space-id exampleString \
    --inject-token=false \
    --entity-product exampleString
```
## • <a name="connection_list">`connection list`</a>
Lists defined connections.

Connections created with shared credentials will return secrets such as database passwords and API keys in clear text. Such secrets are stored encrypted but will be decrypted by the API when retrieved by the caller in order to access the data source defined by the connection. Clear text credentials are allowed because it is understood that the caller has already been explicitly added as a collabaorator in the project or catalog in which the connection is stored and is thus implicitly permitted access to the credentials required to connect to a data source.

Connections created with personal credentials will only display clear text credentials to the same user who provided them.

Use the following parameters to sort the results:

| Field                     | Example                             |
| ------------------------- | ----------------------------------- |
| entity.name               | ?_sort=+entity.name                 |
| metadata.create_time      | ?_sort=-metadata.create_time        |

Use the following parameters to filter the results:

| Field                     | Example                             |
|-------------------------- | ----------------------------------- |
| entity.name               | ?entity.name=MyConnection           |
| entity.datasource_type    | ?entity.datasource_type=<asset_id>  |
| entity.context            | ?entity.context=source              |
| entity.properties         | ?entity.properties={"name":"value"} |
| entity.flags              | ?entity.flags=+personal_credentials |
| metadata.creator_id       | ?metadata.creator_id=userid         |

Filtering is done by specifying the fields to filter on. 

To filter on the properties of a connection, the exact values to  compare must be provided in the entities.properties field and all  values supplied must exactly match a property of a connection.

The entity.flags field specifies the flags a connection can have to be included in the list results. By default, all connections with no flags are returned. 

Adding the name of a flag to entity.flags will add the connections  with that flag to the list results. The name can be optionally  prefixed with a plus sign (+) to indicate that it is being added.

Adding the name of a flag to entity.flags with a minus sign (-) prefix will remove those connections with that flag from the list  results. All additions are done before the subtractions.

```sh
cpdctl connection list [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--sort SORT] [--start START] [--limit LIMIT] [--metadata-creator METADATA-CREATOR] [--entity-name ENTITY-NAME] [--entity-datasource-type ENTITY-DATASOURCE-TYPE] [--entity-context ENTITY-CONTEXT] [--entity-properties ENTITY-PROPERTIES] [--entity-flags ENTITY-FLAGS] [--inject-token=INJECT-TOKEN]
```

#### Command options

`--all-pages` (bool)
:   Invoke multiple requests to display all pages of the collection for list.

    The default value is `false`.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--entity-context` (string)
:   The context of the connection. Can be one of "source", "target", or "source,target".

`--entity-datasource-type` (string)
:   The data source type of the connection.

`--entity-flags` (string)
:   A comma separated list of flags that must be present for the connection to be included in the list. If not provided, only connections with no flags will be returned.

`--entity-name` (string)
:   The name of the connection.

`--entity-properties` (string)
:   The properties of the connection that must match for the connection to be included in the list.

`--inject-token` (bool)
:   Boolean indicator if cluster username and access token should be injected into connection properties. It has to be ensured that access token is not revealed unintentionally together with connection properties.

    The default value is `false`.

`--limit` (int64)
:   The limit of the number of items to return, for example limit=50. If not specified a default of 100 will be  used.

    The default value is `0`.

`--metadata-creator` (string)
:   The creator of the connection.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--sort` (string)
:   The field to sort the results on, including whether to sort ascending (+) or descending (-), for example, sort=-metadata.create_time.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--start` (string)
:   The page token indicating where to start paging from.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl connection list \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id exampleString \
    --space-id exampleString \
    --sort exampleString \
    --start exampleString \
    --limit 10 \
    --metadata-creator exampleString \
    --entity-name exampleString \
    --entity-datasource-type exampleString \
    --entity-context exampleString \
    --entity-properties exampleString \
    --entity-flags exampleString \
    --inject-token=false
```

## • <a name="connection_perform-action">`connection perform-action`</a>
Performs an action on the data source accessed using the connection.

```sh
cpdctl connection perform-action {--connection-id CONNECTION-ID | --connection CONNECTION-NAME} --action-name ACTION-NAME --request REQUEST | @REQUEST-FILE [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}]
```

#### Command options

`--action-name` (string)
:   The name of the action to be performed. This list is expanded over time. The current actions are:

| action                | description                                                              |
| --------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| get_oauth2_tokens     | to get refresh and authorization tokens for sources that support OAuth2. |
| get_record_count      | to get the number of records available for the specified asset.          |
| get_signed_url        | to get a signed URL for accessing a data source.                         |
| test                  | to check if a connection can be established to the data source.          |
| validate              | to validate the connection properties without establishing a connection. |.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--connection` (string)
:   Connection name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--connection-id'.

`--connection-id` (string)
:   The ID of the connection. This option is mutually exclusive with '--connection'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--request` (generic map)
:   The perform action request configuration.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl connection perform-action \
    --connection-id exampleString \
    --action-name get_oauth2_tokens \
    --request '{"anyKey": "anyValue"}' \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id exampleString \
    --space-id exampleString
```
## • <a name="connection_update">`connection update`</a>
Updates the definition of a connection.

```sh
cpdctl connection update {--connection-id CONNECTION-ID | --connection CONNECTION-NAME} --patch-request PATCH-REQUEST | @PATCH-REQUEST-FILE [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--test=TEST] [--skip-enforcement=SKIP-ENFORCEMENT]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--connection` (string)
:   Connection name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--connection-id'.

`--connection-id` (string)
:   The ID of the connection. This option is mutually exclusive with '--connection'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--patch-request` ([`JSONPatchOperation[]`](#cli-json-patch-operation-example-schema))
:   Fields to update within the connection.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id, project_id, or space_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--skip-enforcement` (bool)
:   The indicator whether shared credentials disablement and vault credentials enforcement guards should be disabled for creation and updates.

`--space` (string)

## • <a name="connection_datasource-type_get">`connection datasource-type get`</a>
Get details for type of data source.

```sh
cpdctl connection datasource-type get --datasource-type DATASOURCE-TYPE [--accept-language ACCEPT-LANGUAGE] [--connection-properties=CONNECTION-PROPERTIES] [--interaction-properties=INTERACTION-PROPERTIES] [--discovery=DISCOVERY] [--actions=ACTIONS] [--entity-environment ENTITY-ENVIRONMENT] [--entity-product ENTITY-PRODUCT] [--product-selector-scope PRODUCT-SELECTOR-SCOPE] [--generate-transitive-conditions=GENERATE-TRANSITIVE-CONDITIONS]
```

#### Command options

`--accept-language` (string)
:   The user's preferred locale identifier.

`--actions` (bool)
:   Whether to return information about supported actions.

    The default value is `false`.

`--connection-properties` (bool)
:   Whether to return information about connection properties.

    The default value is `false`.

`--datasource-type` (string)
:   The data source type.

`--discovery` (bool)
:   Whether to return information about discovery capabilities.

    The default value is `false`.

`--entity-environment` (string)
:   Specify the environment the data source type must support to be returned. The available environments are 'cloud', 'streams' and 'local'. If no entity.environment is specified, no filtering is applied. To specify multiple environments, use a comma-separated string, such as entity.environment=cloud,streams.

`--entity-product` (string)
:   Specify the product the data source type must support to be returned. The available products are 'catalog', 'cpd', 'datastage', 'dv', 'igc', 'mdi', 'ml' and 'studio'. If no entity.product is specified, no filtering is applied. To specify multiple products, use a comma-separated string, such as entity.product=catalog,studio.

`--generate-transitive-conditions` (bool)
:   Whether to generate extra conditions in common properties format that will make them behave in a transitive manner under default configuration options of Elyra i.e. when a condition is part of a chain it will enable/disable everything down the chain rather than just hiding the control. Support for this option has been removed. Option itself was not removed to preserve binary compatibility but it no longer has any effect.

    The default value is `false`.

`--interaction-properties` (bool)
:   Whether to return information about source and target interaction properties.

    The default value is `false`.

`--product-selector-scope` (string)
:   Scope of ui-only product selector property. Applies to output under common_properties key. Genreated ui contains additional checkbox to switch between first of the requested products and the rest. If only a single one is given it switches between that product and remaining products supported by the data source.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl connection datasource-type get \
    --datasource-type exampleString \
    --accept-language en-US \
    --connection-properties=true \
    --interaction-properties=true \
    --discovery=true \
    --actions=true \
    --entity-environment exampleString \
    --entity-product exampleString \
    --product-selector-scope global \
    --generate-transitive-conditions=false
```

## • <a name="datastage_codegen_generate-buildop">`datastage codegen generate-buildop`</a>
Generate the runtime assets for a DataStage buildop in the specified project or catalog for a specified runtime type. Either project_id or catalog_id must be specified.

```sh
cpdctl datastage codegen generate-buildop [command options]
```

## • <a name="datastage_flow_compile">`datastage flow compile`</a>
Generate the runtime assets for a DataStage flow in the specified project or catalog for a specified runtime type. Either project_id or catalog_id must be specified.

```sh
cpdctl datastage flow compile --flow-id FLOW-ID [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--runtime-type RUNTIME-TYPE] [--enable-sql-pushdown=ENABLE-SQL-PUSHDOWN] [--enable-async-compile=ENABLE-ASYNC-COMPILE] [--enable-native-sql-pushdown=ENABLE-NATIVE-SQL-PUSHDOWN] [--enable-push-processing-to-source=ENABLE-PUSH-PROCESSING-TO-SOURCE] [--enable-push-join-to-source=ENABLE-PUSH-JOIN-TO-SOURCE]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--enable-async-compile` (bool)
:   Whether to compile the flow asynchronously or not. When set to true, the compile request will be queued and then compiled. Response will be returned immediately as "Compiling". For compile status, call get compile status api.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-native-sql-pushdown` (bool)
:   Whether to enable the Native SQL pushdown code generation or not. When this flag is set to true and enable_push_processing_to_source is not specified, enable_push_processing_to_source will be automatically set to true as well. When this flag is set to true and enable_push_join_to_source is not speicified, enable_push_join_to_source will be automatically set to true as well.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-push-join-to-source` (bool)
:   Whether to enable pushing join/lookup stages to source connectors or not. Setting this flag to true will automatically set enable_native_sql_pushdown to true if the latter is not specified or is explicitly set to false.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-push-processing-to-source` (bool)
:   Whether to enable pushing processing stages to source connectors or not. Setting this flag to true will automatically set enable_native_sql_pushdown to true if the latter is not specified or is explicitly set to false.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-sql-pushdown` (bool)
:   Whether to enable the SQL pushdown code generation or not.

    The default value is `false`.

`--flow-id` (string)
:   The DataStage flow ID to use.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--runtime-type` (string)
:   The type of the runtime to use. e.g. dspxosh or Spark etc. If not provided queried from within pipeline flow if available otherwise default of dspxosh is used.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage flow compile \
    --flow-id exampleString \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --runtime-type exampleString \
    --enable-sql-pushdown=true \
    --enable-async-compile=true \
    --enable-native-sql-pushdown=true \
    --enable-push-processing-to-source=true \
    --enable-push-join-to-source=true
```

## • <a name="datastage_flow_delete">`datastage flow delete`</a>
Deletes the specified data flows in a project or catalog (either `project_id` or `catalog_id` must be set).

If the deletion of the data flows and their runs will take some time to finish, then a 202 response will be returned and the deletion will continue asynchronously.
         All the data flow runs associated with the data flows will also be deleted. If a data flow is still running, it will not be deleted unless the force parameter is set to true. If a data flow is still running and the force parameter is set to true, the call returns immediately with a 202 response. The related data flows are deleted after the data flow runs are stopped.

```sh
cpdctl datastage flow delete --flow-id FLOW-ID [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--force=FORCE]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--flow-id` (string)
:   The list of DataStage flow IDs to delete.

`--force` (bool)
:   Whether to stop all running data flows. Running DataStage flows must be stopped before the DataStage flows can be deleted.

    The default value is `false`.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage flow delete \
    --flow-id exampleString,anotherTestString \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --force=true
```

## • <a name="datastage_flow_list">`datastage flow list`</a>
Lists the metadata, entity and lock information for DataStage flows that are contained in the specified project. 

Use the following parameters to filter the results:

| Field                    | Match type   | Example                                 |
| ------------------------ | ------------ | --------------------------------------- |
| `entity.name`              | Equals           | `entity.name=MyDataStageFlow`  |
| `entity.name`              | Starts with      | `entity.name=starts:MyData`  |
| `entity.description`       | Equals           | `entity.description=movement`  |
| `entity.description`       | Starts with      | `entity.description=starts:data`  |

To sort the results, use one or more of the parameters  described in the following section. If no sort key is specified, the results are sorted in descending order on `metadata.create_time` (i.e. returning the most  recently created data flows first).

| Field                          | Example |
| ------------------------- | ----------------------------------- |
| sort     | `sort=+entity.name` (sort by ascending name)  |
| sort     | `sort=-metadata.create_time` (sort by descending creation time) |

Multiple sort keys can be specified by delimiting them with a comma. For example, to sort in descending order on `create_time` and then in ascending order on name use: `sort=-metadata.create_time`,`+entity.name`.

```sh
cpdctl datastage flow list [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--sort SORT] [--start START] [--limit LIMIT] [--name NAME] [--description DESCRIPTION]
```

#### Command options

`--all-pages` (bool)
:   Invoke multiple requests to display all pages of the collection for flow-list.

    The default value is `false`.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--description` (string)
:   Filter results based on the specified description.

`--limit` (int64)
:   The limit of the number of items to return, for example limit=50. If not specified a default of 100 will be  used.

    The default value is `0`.

`--name` (string)
:   Filter results based on the specified name.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--sort` (string)
:   The field to sort the results on, including whether to sort ascending (+) or descending (-), for example, sort=-metadata.create_time.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--start` (string)
:   The page token indicating where to start paging from.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage flow list \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --sort exampleString \
```

## • <a name="datastage_flow_patch-attributes">`datastage flow patch-attributes`</a>

`--catalog` (string)

`--directory-asset-id` (string)

`--flow-id` (string)

`--name` (string)
:   name of the asset.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage flow patch-attributes \

    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \

```
## • <a name="datastage_flow_update">`datastage flow update`</a>
Modifies a data flow in the specified project or catalog (either `project_id` or `catalog_id` must be set). All subsequent calls to use the data flow must specify the project or catalog ID the data flow was created in.

```sh
cpdctl datastage flow update [command options]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--directory-asset-id` (string)
:   The directory asset ID.

`--flow-id` (string)
:   The DataStage flow ID to use.

`--name` (string)
:   The data flow name.

`--pipeline-flow` ([`PipelineJSON`](#cli-pipeline-json-example-schema))
:   Pipeline flow to be stored.

`--pipeline-flows-app-data` (generic map)
:   Object containing app-specific data.

`--pipeline-flows-doc-type` (string)
:   The document type.

`--pipeline-flows-external-paramsets` ([]map[string]interface{})
:   Array of parameter set references.

`--pipeline-flows-id` (string)
:   Document identifier, GUID recommended.

`--pipeline-flows-json-schema` (string)
:   Refers to the JSON schema used to validate documents of this type.

`--pipeline-flows-parameters` (generic map)
:   Parameters for the flow document.

`--pipeline-flows-pipelines` ([`Pipelines[]`](#cli-pipelines-example-schema))
:   null It can also be a path to a JSON file.

`--pipeline-flows-primary-pipeline` (string)
:   Reference to the primary (main) pipeline flow within the document.

`--pipeline-flows-runtimes` ([]map[string]interface{})
:   Runtime information for pipeline flow.

`--pipeline-flows-schemas` ([]map[string]interface{})
:   Array of data record schemas used in the pipeline.

`--pipeline-flows-version` (string)
:   Pipeline flow version.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage flow update \
    --flow-id exampleString \
    --name exampleString \
    --pipeline-flow '{"app_data": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "doc_type": "pipeline", "external_paramsets": [{"anyKey": "anyValue"},{"anotherAnyKey": "anotherAnyValue"}], "id": "84c2b6fb-1dd5-4114-b4ba-9bb2cb364fff", "json_schema": "http://api.dataplatform.ibm.com/schemas/common-pipeline/pipeline-flow/pipeline-flow-v3-schema.json", "parameters": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "pipelines": [{"app_data": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "description": "A test DataStage flow.", "id": "fa1b859a-d592-474d-b56c-2137e4efa4bc", "name": "ContainerC1", "nodes": [{"anyKey": "anyValue"},{"anotherAnyKey": "anotherAnyValue"}], "runtime_ref": "pxOsh"}], "primary_pipeline": "fa1b859a-d592-474d-b56c-2137e4efa4bc", "runtimes": [{"anyKey": "anyValue"},{"anotherAnyKey": "anotherAnyValue"}], "schemas": [{"anyKey": "anyValue"},{"anotherAnyKey": "anotherAnyValue"}], "version": "3.0"}' \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --directory-asset-id exampleString
```
## • <a name="datastage_migration_create">`datastage migration create`</a>
Creates data flows from the attached job export file. This is an asynchronous call. The API call returns almost immediately which does not necessarily imply the completion of the import request. It only means that the import request has been accepted. The status field of the import request is included in the import response object. The status "completed" ("in_progress", "failed", resp.) indicates the import request is completed (in progress, and failed, resp.) The job export file for an import request may contain one mor more data flows. Unless the on_failure option is set to "stop", a completed import request may contain not only successfully imported data flows but also data flows that cannot be imported.

```sh
cpdctl datastage migration create [command options]
```

#### Command options

`--asset-type` (string)
:   Asset types separated by commas (','). Only assets of these types will be imported. If not specified, all supported assets will be imported.

`--attachment-type` (string)
:   Type of attachment. The default attachment type is "isx".

`--body` (io.ReadCloser)
:   The ISX file to import. The maximum file size is 1GB.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--conflict-resolution` (string)
:   Resolution when data flow to be imported has a name conflict with an existing data flow in the project or catalog. The default conflict resolution is "skip" will skip the data flow so that it will not be imported. The "rename" resolution will append "_Import_NNNN" suffix to the original name and use the new name for the imported data flow, while the "replace" resolution will first remove the existing data flow with the same name and import the new data flow. For the "rename_replace" option, when the flow name is already used, a new flow name with the suffix
"_DATASTAGE_ISX_IMPORT" will be used. If the name is not currently used, the imported flow will be created with this name. In case the new name is already used, the existing flow will be removed  first before the imported flow is created. With the rename_replace option, job creation will be determined as follows. If the job name is already used, a new job name with the suffix ".DataStage job" will be used. If the new job name is not currently used, the job will be created with this name. In case the new job name is already used, the job creation will not happen and an error will be raised.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--create-connection-parametersets` (bool)
:   Create generic parameter sets for default connection values migration. Default value is true.

    The default value is `false`.

`--create-missing-parameters` (bool)
:   Create missing parameter sets and job parameters.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-folder` (bool)
:   Enable folder support.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-local-connection` (bool)
:   enable local connection migration. Default value is false.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-notification` (bool)
:   enable/disable notification. Default value is true.

    The default value is `false`.

`--enable-rulestage-integration` (bool)
:   enable/disable wkc rule stage migration. Default value is false.

    The default value is `false`.

`--file-name` (string)
:   Name of the input file, if it exists.

`--from` (string)
:   Migrate from which stage.

`--import-only` (bool)
:   Skip flow compilation.

    The default value is `false`.

`--migrate-hive-impala` (bool)
:   Will migrate hive isx connections to impala.

    The default value is `false`.

`--migrate-to-platform-connection` (bool)
:   Will migrate all isx connections to available platform connections instead of their datastage optimized versions.

    The default value is `false`.

`--migrate-to-send-email` (bool)
:   Will migrate all notification activitie stages in sequence job to send email task nodes.

    The default value is `false`.

`--on-failure` (string)
:   Action when the first import failure occurs. The default action is "continue" which will continue importing the remaining data flows. The "stop" action will stop the import operation upon the first error.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--replace-mode` (string)
:   This paramter take effect when conflict_resolution is set to replace or skip. soft- merge the parameter set, add new parameter only, keep the old value sets hard- replace all.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--storage-path` (string)
:   Folder path of the storage volume for routine scripts and other data assets.

`--to` (string)
:   Migrate to which stage.

`--use-dsn-name` (bool)
:   Enables private cloud migration of ODBC connector 'datasource' to 'dsn_name' instead of generating parameter references. Default is false.

    The default value is `false`.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage migration create \
    --body tempdir/test-file.txt \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --on-failure continue \
    --conflict-resolution rename \
    --attachment-type isx \
    --file-name myFlows.isx \
    --enable-notification=false \
    --import-only=false \
    --create-missing-parameters=false \
    --enable-rulestage-integration=false \
    --enable-local-connection=false \
    --asset-type data_intg_flow,parameter_set \
    --create-connection-parametersets=false \
    --storage-path /mnts/my-script-storage \
    --replace-mode hard \
    --migrate-to-platform-connection=false \
    --use-dsn-name=false \
    --migrate-to-send-email=false \
    --enable-folder=false \
    --migrate-hive-impala=false \
    --from Db2ConnectorPX \
    --to Db2zos
```
## • <a name="datastage_migration_create-from-zip">`datastage migration create-from-zip`</a>
Creates data flows from the attached job export file. This is an asynchronous call. The API call returns almost immediately which does not necessarily imply the completion of the import request. It only means that the import request has been accepted. The status field of the import request is included in the import response object. The status "completed" ("in_progress", "failed", resp.) indicates the import request is completed (in progress, and failed, resp.) The job export file for an import request may contain one mor more data flows. Unless the on_failure option is set to "stop", a completed import request may contain not only successfully imported data flows but also data flows that cannot be imported.

```sh
cpdctl datastage migration create-from-zip --body BODY [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--on-failure ON-FAILURE] [--conflict-resolution CONFLICT-RESOLUTION] [--file-name FILE-NAME] [--enable-notification=ENABLE-NOTIFICATION] [--import-only=IMPORT-ONLY] [--include-dependencies=INCLUDE-DEPENDENCIES] [--asset-type ASSET-TYPE] [--skip-dependencies SKIP-DEPENDENCIES] [--replace-mode REPLACE-MODE] [--x-migration-enc-key X-MIGRATION-ENC-KEY]
```

#### Command options

`--asset-type` (string)
:   Asset types separated by commas (','). Only assets of these types will be imported. If not specified, all supported assets will be imported.

`--body` (io.ReadCloser)
:   The zip file to import. The maximum file size is 1GB.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--conflict-resolution` (string)
:   Resolution when data flow to be imported has a name conflict with an existing data flow in the project or catalog. The default conflict resolution is "skip" will skip the data flow so that it will not be imported. The "rename" resolution will append "_Import_NNNN" suffix to the original name and use the new name for the imported data flow, while the "replace" resolution will first remove the existing data flow with the same name and import the new data flow. For the "rename_replace" option, when the flow name is already used, a new flow name with the suffix
"_DATASTAGE_ISX_IMPORT" will be used. If the name is not currently used, the imported flow will be created with this name. In case the new name is already used, the existing flow will be removed  first before the imported flow is created. With the rename_replace option, job creation will be determined as follows. If the job name is already used, a new job name with the suffix ".DataStage job" will be used. If the new job name is not currently used, the job will be created with this name. In case the new job name is already used, the job creation will not happen and an error will be raised.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--enable-notification` (bool)
:   enable/disable notification. Default value is true.

    The default value is `false`.

`--file-name` (string)
:   Name of the input file, if it exists.

`--import-only` (bool)
:   Skip flow compilation.

    The default value is `false`.

`--include-dependencies` (bool)
:   If set to false, skip dependencies, only import flow. If not specified or set to true, import flow and dependencies.

    The default value is `false`.

`--on-failure` (string)
:   Action when the first import failure occurs. The default action is "continue" which will continue importing the remaining data flows. The "stop" action will stop the import operation upon the first error.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--replace-mode` (string)
:   This paramter take effect when conflict_resolution is set to replace or skip. soft- merge the parameter set, add new parameter only, keep the old value sets hard- replace all.

`--skip-dependencies` (string)
:   Skip dependencies separated by commas (','), it is only used with replace option. If specified the skiped dependencies, only assets of these types will be skiped if the assets are existed.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--x-migration-enc-key` (string)
:   The encryption key to encrypt credentials on export or to decrypt them on import.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage migration create-from-zip \
    --body tempdir/test-file.txt \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --on-failure continue \
    --conflict-resolution rename \
    --file-name myFlows.isx \
    --enable-notification=false \
    --import-only=false \
    --include-dependencies=false \
    --asset-type data_intg_flow,parameter_set \
    --skip-dependencies connection,parameter_set,subflow \
    --replace-mode hard \
    --x-migration-enc-key exampleString
```

## • <a name="datastage_migration_export-flows-with-dependencies">`datastage migration export-flows-with-dependencies`</a>
export flows with dependencies as a zip file.

```sh
cpdctl datastage migration export-flows-with-dependencies --flows FLOWS | @FLOWS-FILE [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--remove-secrets=REMOVE-SECRETS] [--include-dependencies=INCLUDE-DEPENDENCIES] [--id ID] [--type TYPE] [--include-data-assets=INCLUDE-DATA-ASSETS] [--exclude-data-files=EXCLUDE-DATA-FILES] [--x-migration-enc-key X-MIGRATION-ENC-KEY]
```

#### Command options

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--exclude-data-files` (bool)
:   skip the actual data files for datastage dataset and fileset when exporting flows as zip.

    The default value is `false`.

`--flows` ([`FlowDependencyTree[]`](#cli-flow-dependency-tree-example-schema))
:   list of flows and their dependencies.

`--id` (string)
:   The list of DataStage flow IDs to export.

`--include-data-assets` (bool)
:   include data_assets. If set as true, all referenced data_assets will be included.

    The default value is `false`.

`--include-dependencies` (bool)
:   include dependencies. If no dependencies are specified in the payload, all dependencies will be included.

    The default value is `false`.

`--output-file` (string)
:   Filename/path to write the resulting output to.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--remove-secrets` (bool)
:   remove secrets from exported flows.

    The default value is `false`.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--type` (string)
:   Type of flow. The default flow type is "data_intg_flow". It is only used with 'id' parameter.

`--x-migration-enc-key` (string)
:   The encryption key to encrypt credentials on export or to decrypt them on import.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage migration export-flows-with-dependencies \
    --flows '[{"dependencies": [{"id": "exampleString", "name": "exampleString", "type": "exampleString"}], "id": "exampleString", "name": "exampleString", "type": "data_intg_flow", "volatile": true}]' \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --remove-secrets=false \
    --include-dependencies=false \
    --id exampleString,anotherTestString \
    --type exampleString \
    --include-data-assets=false \
    --exclude-data-files=false \
    --x-migration-enc-key exampleString \
    --output-file tempdir/example-output.txt
```

`--space` (string)

```sh
   cpdctl datastage migration get \
```

## • <a name="datastage_subflow_list">`datastage subflow list`</a>
Lists the metadata, entity and lock information for DataStage subflows that are contained in the specified project. 

Use the following parameters to filter the results:

| Field                    | Match type   | Example                                 |
| ------------------------ | ------------ | --------------------------------------- |
| `entity.name`              | Equals           | `entity.name=MyDataStageSubFlow`  |
| `entity.name`              | Starts with      | `entity.name=starts:MyData`  |
| `entity.description`       | Equals           | `entity.description=movement`  |
| `entity.description`       | Starts with      | `entity.description=starts:data`  |

To sort the results, use one or more of the parameters  described in the following section. If no sort key is specified, the results are sorted in descending order on `metadata.create_time` (i.e. returning the most  recently created data flows first).

| Field                          | Example |
| ------------------------- | ----------------------------------- |
| sort     | `sort=+entity.name` (sort by ascending name)  |
| sort     | `sort=-metadata.create_time` (sort by descending creation time) |

Multiple sort keys can be specified by delimiting them with a comma. For example, to sort in descending order on `create_time` and then in ascending order on name use: `sort=-metadata.create_time`,`+entity.name`.

```sh
cpdctl datastage subflow list [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--sort SORT] [--start START] [--limit LIMIT] [--name NAME] [--description DESCRIPTION]
```

#### Command options

`--all-pages` (bool)
:   Invoke multiple requests to display all pages of the collection for subflow-list.

    The default value is `false`.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--description` (string)
:   Filter results based on the specified description.

`--limit` (int64)
:   The limit of the number of items to return, for example limit=50. If not specified a default of 100 will be  used.

    The default value is `0`.

`--name` (string)
:   Filter results based on the specified name.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--sort` (string)
:   The field to sort the results on, including whether to sort ascending (+) or descending (-), for example, sort=-metadata.create_time.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. 'catalog_id' or 'project_id' or 'space_id' is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--start` (string)
:   The page token indicating where to start paging from.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage subflow list \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id 4c9adbb4-28ef-4a7d-b273-1cee0c38021f \
    --sort exampleString \
    --start bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e2 \
    --limit 100 \
    --name exampleString \
    --description exampleString
```

```sh
cpdctl datastage table-definition create [--entity (ENTITY | @ENTITY-FILE) | --entity-column-info ENTITY-COLUMN-INFO --entity-data-asset ENTITY-DATA-ASSET --entity-data-definition ENTITY-DATA-DEFINITION --entity-directory-asset ENTITY-DIRECTORY-ASSET --entity-ds-info ENTITY-DS-INFO] [--metadata (METADATA | @METADATA-FILE) | --metadata-description METADATA-DESCRIPTION --metadata-name METADATA-NAME] [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--directory-asset-id DIRECTORY-ASSET-ID] [--asset-category ASSET-CATEGORY]
```

#### Command options

`--asset-category` (string)
:   The category of the asset. Must be either SYSTEM or USER. Only a registered service can use this parameter.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id or project_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--directory-asset-id` (string)
:   The directory asset id to create the asset in or move to.

`--entity` ([`TableDefinitionEntity`](#cli-table-definition-entity-example-schema))
:   The underlying table definition.

`--entity-column-info` (generic map)
:   null It can also be a path to a JSON file.

`--entity-data-asset` ([`TableDefinitionDataAsset`](#cli-table-definition-data-asset-example-schema))
:   column definitions and table properties.

`--entity-data-definition` (generic map)
:   null It can also be a path to a JSON file.

`--entity-directory-asset` ([`DirectoryAsset`](#cli-directory-asset-example-schema))
:   null It can also be a path to a JSON file.

`--entity-ds-info` ([`TableDefinitionDSInfo`](#cli-table-definition-ds-info-example-schema))
:   data type defaults and format properties.

`--metadata` ([`TableDefinitionMetadata`](#cli-table-definition-metadata-example-schema))
:   System metadata about a table definition.

`--metadata-description` (string)
:   table definition description.

`--metadata-name` (string)
:   table definition name.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id or project_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. catalog_id, space_id, or project_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage table-definition create \
    --entity '{"column_info": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "data_asset": {"additionalProperties": "exampleString", "columns": [{"name": "exampleString", "properties": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "type": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}}], "dataset": true, "mime_type": "exampleString"}, "data_definition": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "directory_asset": {"path": "exampleString"}, "ds_info": {"data_types": ["exampleString","anotherTestString"], "field_defaults": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "record_level": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "type_defaults": {"date": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "decimal": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "general": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "numeric": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "string": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "time": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}, "timestamp": {"anyKey": "anyValue"}}}}' \
    --metadata '{"description": "exampleString", "name": "exampleString"}' \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id exampleString \
    --directory-asset-id exampleString \
    --asset-category SYSTEM
```

## • <a name="datastage_table-definition_list">`datastage table-definition list`</a>
Lists the table definitions that are contained in the specified project or catalog (either project_id or catalog_id must be set).

Use the following parameters to filter the results:

| Field                    | Match type   | Example                                 |
| ------------------------ | ------------ | --------------------------------------- |
| asset.name              | Starts with  | ?asset.name=starts:MyTable |
| asset.description          | Equals   | ?asset.description=starts:profiling           |

To sort the returned results, use one or more of the parameters described in the following section. If no sort key is specified, the results are sorted in descending order on metadata.create_time, returning the most  recently created data flows first.

| Field                     | Example                             |
| ------------------------- | ----------------------------------- |
| asset.name               | ?sort=+asset.name                  |
| metadata.create_time      | ?sort=-metadata.create_time         |

Multiple sort keys can be specified by delimiting them with a comma. For example, to sort in descending order on create_time and then in ascending order on name use: `?sort=-metadata.create_time,+asset.name.

```sh
cpdctl datastage table-definition list [{--catalog-id CATALOG-ID | --catalog CATALOG-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [--sort SORT] [--start START] [--limit LIMIT] [--name NAME] [--description DESCRIPTION]
```

#### Command options

`--all-pages` (bool)
:   Invoke multiple requests to display all pages of the collection for table-definition-list.

    The default value is `false`.

`--catalog` (string)
:   Catalog name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog-id'.

`--catalog-id` (string)
:   The ID of the catalog to use. catalog_id or project_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--catalog'.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project or catalog scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--description` (string)
:   Filter results based on the specified description.

`--limit` (int64)
:   The limit of the number of items to return, for example limit=50. If not specified a default of 100 will be  used.

    The default value is `0`.

`--name` (string)
:   Filter results based on the specified name.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The ID of the project to use. catalog_id or project_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--sort` (string)
:   The field to sort the results on, including whether to sort ascending (+) or descending (-), for example, sort=-metadata.create_time.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The ID of the space to use. catalog_id, space_id, or project_id is required. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--start` (string)
:   The page token indicating where to start paging from.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl datastage table-definition list \
    --catalog-id exampleString \
    --project-id bd0dbbfd-810d-4f0e-b0a9-228c328a8e23 \
    --space-id exampleString \
    --sort exampleString \
    --start exampleString \
    --limit 100 \
    --name exampleString \
    --description exampleString
```

## • <a name="environment_create">`environment create`</a>
Create Environment.

You need to specify either `project_id` or `space_id`.

Required body parameters vary dependent on environment types:
- notebook: `type`, `name`, `display_name`, `hardware_specification`, `software_specification`, `tools_specification`, `runtime_definition`
- datastage: `type`, `name`, `display_name`, `hardware_specification`
- other types: `type`, `name`, `display_name`, `hardware_specification`, `software_specification`.

```sh
cpdctl environment create [command options]
```

#### Command options

`--authorization-variables` (generic map)
:   Authorization variables for the environment.

`--compute-specification` (generic map)
:   Compute specification of the environment.

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--description` (string)
:   Description of the environment.

`--display-name` (string)
:   Display name of the environment.

`--environment-variables` (generic map)
:   Environment variables for the environment.

`--hardware-specification` ([`ReferencedSpecification`](#cli-referenced-specification-example-schema))
:   A pointer to a sub-specification that was defined elsewhere.

`--hardware-specification-guid` (string)
:   A UUID of an existing specification.

`--hardware-specification-type` (string)
:   Always "referenced". Allowable values are: referenced.

`--location` (generic map)
:   Runtime location for the environment.

`--name` (string)
:   Name of the environment.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The id of the project. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--runtime-definition` (string)
:   Runtime definition for the environment.

`--runtime-idle-time` (int64)
:   Runtime idle timeout.

    The default value is `0`.

`--software-specification` ([`ReferencedSpecification`](#cli-referenced-specification-example-schema))
:   A pointer to a sub-specification that was defined elsewhere.

`--software-specification-guid` (string)
:   A UUID of an existing specification.

`--software-specification-type` (string)
:   Always "referenced". Allowable values are: referenced.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The id of the space. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--tools-specification` (generic map)
:   Tools specification for the environment.

`--type` (string)
:   Type of the environment.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl environment create \
    --display-name 'my notebook environment with special chars!' \
    --hardware-specification '{"guid": "b82b95df-fc3e-4273-98f7-473d62a03c2b", "type": "referenced"}' \
    --name 'my notebook environment' \
    --software-specification '{"guid": "b82b95df-fc3e-4273-98f7-473d62a03c2b", "type": "referenced"}' \
    --type notebook \
    --authorization-variables '{"anyKey": "anyValue"}' \
    --compute-specification '{"anyKey": "anyValue"}' \
    --description 'this is my notebook environment' \
    --environment-variables '{"anyKey": "anyValue"}' \
    --location '{"anyKey": "anyValue"}' \
    --runtime-definition 204dac19-7d94-4692-a4c8-2acd77e28792 \
    --runtime-idle-time 1800000 \
    --tools-specification '{"anyKey": "anyValue"}' \
    --project-id 92ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --space-id 82ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4
```

## • <a name="environment_hardware-specification_create">`environment hardware-specification create`</a>
Create Hardware Specification.

Specify either space_id or project_id, or none of them. This makes 3 valid cases, which are:

(1) When specifying project_id, the hardware specification is scoped to that particular project only.
(2) When specifying space_id, the hardware specification is scoped to that particular space only.
(3) When specifying no scope (neither project_id nor space_id), the hardware specification is a global custom hardware specification.

Global default hardware specifications are read from a well-known location on disk, and therefore cannot be created through the API.

Authorization rules for (1) and (2) follow those for `/v2/assets` for projects and spaces, respectively. Alternatively, the request is authorized for a valid authentication by Service Auth. Only WSL/CPD administrators are authorized to make a request of type (3) - global custom software specifications. Alternatively, the request is authorized for a valid authentication by Service Auth.

You can only provide exactly one of `nodes`, `spark` or `datastage`, not at the same time.

```sh
cpdctl environment hardware-specification create [command options]
```

#### Command options

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--datastage` ([`HardwareSpecificationDataStageDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-data-stage-definition-example-schema))
:   DataStage definition of hardware specification.

`--datastage-compute` ([`HardwareSpecificationDataStageComputeDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-data-stage-compute-definition-example-schema))
:   DataStage compute definition of hardware specification.

`--datastage-conductor` ([`HardwareSpecificationDataStageConductorDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-data-stage-conductor-definition-example-schema))
:   DataStage conductor definition of hardware specification.

`--datastage-instance` (string)
:   Instance of DataStage.

`--datastage-num-computes` (int64)
:   Number of computes.

    The default value is `0`.

`--datastage-num-conductors` (int64)
:   Number of conductors.

    The default value is `0`.

`--description` (string)
:   Description of hardware specification.

`--name` (string)
:   Name of hardware specification.

`--nodes` ([`HardwareSpecificationNodesDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-nodes-definition-example-schema))
:   Compute node definition of hardware specification.

`--nodes-cpu` ([`HardwareSpecificationCpuDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-cpu-definition-example-schema))
:   (Fraction of) number of CPUs of hardware specification.

`--nodes-gpu` ([`HardwareSpecificationGpuDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-gpu-definition-example-schema))
:   GPU definition of hardware specification.

`--nodes-mem` ([`HardwareSpecificationMemoryDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-memory-definition-example-schema))
:   Memory size of hardware specification.

`--nodes-num-nodes` (int64)
:   Number of compute nodes.

    The default value is `0`.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The id of the project in which to create the hardware specification. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The id of the space. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--spark` ([`HardwareSpecificationSparkDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-spark-definition-example-schema))
:   Spark definition of hardware specification.

`--spark-driver` ([`HardwareSpecificationSparkDriverDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-spark-driver-definition-example-schema))
:   Spark driver definition of hardware specification.

`--spark-executor` ([`HardwareSpecificationSparkExecutorDefinition`](#cli-hardware-specification-spark-executor-definition-example-schema))
:   Spark executor definition of hardware specification.

`--spark-num-drivers` (int64)
:   Number of drivers.

    The default value is `0`.

`--spark-num-executors` (int64)
:   Number of executors.

    The default value is `0`.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl environment hardware-specification create \
    --name 'my hardware specification' \
    --datastage '{"compute": {"cpu": {"model": "exampleString", "units": "100m"}, "mem": {"size": "4Gi"}}, "conductor": {"cpu": {"model": "exampleString", "units": "100m"}, "mem": {"size": "4Gi"}}, "instance": "instance-1", "num_computes": 2, "num_conductors": 1}' \
    --description 'this is my hardware specification' \
    --nodes '{"cpu": {"model": "exampleString", "units": "100m"}, "gpu": {"name": "v100", "num_gpu": 2}, "mem": {"size": "4Gi"}, "num_nodes": 1}' \
    --spark '{"driver": {"cpu": {"model": "exampleString", "units": "100m"}, "mem": {"size": "4Gi"}}, "executor": {"cpu": {"model": "exampleString", "units": "100m"}, "mem": {"size": "4Gi"}}, "num_drivers": 1, "num_executors": 2}' \
    --space-id 82ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --project-id exampleString
```
## • <a name="environment_hardware-specification_delete">`environment hardware-specification delete`</a>
Delete a particular hardware specification`.

Specify either space_id or project_id, or none of them. This makes 3 valid cases, which are:

(1) When specifying project_id, the hardware specification is scoped to that particular project only.
(2) When specifying space_id, the hardware specification is scoped to that particular space only.
(3) When specifying no scope (neither project_id nor space_id), the hardware specification must a global custom hardware specification.

Global default hardware specifications are read from a well-known location on disk, and therefore cannot be deleted through the API.

Authorization rules for (1) and (2) follow those for `/v2/assets` for projects and spaces, respectively. Alternatively, the request is authorized for a valid authentication by Service Auth. Only WSL/CPD administrators are authorized to make a request of type (3) - global custom hardware specifications. Alternatively, the request is authorized for a valid authentication by Service Auth.

```sh
cpdctl environment hardware-specification delete --hardware-specification-id HARDWARE-SPECIFICATION-ID [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}]
```

#### Command options

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--hardware-specification` (string)
:   Hardware specification name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--hardware-specification-id'.

`--hardware-specification-id` (string)
:   The guid of the hardware specification. This option is mutually exclusive with '--hardware-specification'.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The id of the project. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The id of the space. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl environment hardware-specification delete \
    --hardware-specification-id a1da1d73-5eb5-4dfb-808e-174eb153c20e \
    --space-id 82ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --project-id 92ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4
```
## • <a name="environment_hardware-specification_get">`environment hardware-specification get`</a>
Retrieve a particular hardware specification.

Specify either space_id or project_id, or none of them. This makes 4 valid cases, which are:

(1) When specifying project_id, the returned hardware specification can be a
  (a) Hardware specification that is scoped to that project only.
  (b) Global hardware specification as global hardware specifications are valid in any scope.
(2) When specifying space_id, the returned hardware specification can be a
  (a) Hardware specification that is scoped to that space only.
  (b) Global hardware specification as global hardware specifications are valid in any scope.
(3) When specifying no scope (neither project_id nor space_id), and the hardware specification is a global custom hardware specification.
(4) When specifying no scope (neither project_id nor space_id), and the hardware specification is a global default hardware specification.

(1) and (2) follow authorization rules of `/v2/assets` for project and space access, respectively. Alternatively, the request is authorized for a valid authentication by Service Auth.
(3) and (4) retrieve global hardware specifications, which any WSL/CPD user is authorized for.

```sh
cpdctl environment hardware-specification get --hardware-specification-id HARDWARE-SPECIFICATION-ID [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}]
```

#### Command options

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--hardware-specification` (string)
:   Hardware specification name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--hardware-specification-id'.

`--hardware-specification-id` (string)
:   The guid of the hardware specification. This option is mutually exclusive with '--hardware-specification'.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The id of the project. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The id of the space. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl environment hardware-specification get \
    --hardware-specification-id a1da1d73-5eb5-4dfb-808e-174eb153c20e \
    --space-id 82ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --project-id 92ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4
```
## • <a name="environment_hardware-specification_list">`environment hardware-specification list`</a>
List all hardware specifications.

Always includes all global (default and custom) hardware specifications, independent of whether space_id or project_id is present. When specifying project_id or space_id (parameters that are mutually exclusive, i.e., cannot both be provided), the list includes
(1) all scoped hardware specifications scoped to that project or space, respectively.
(2) all global default hardware specifications.
(3) all global custom hardware specifications.

If project_id or space_id is provided, access permissions for the requesting user follow `/v2/assets` rules for projects or spaces, respectively. If neither project_id nor space_id are provided, returns only global (default and custom) hardware specifications, which can be retrieved by any WSL/CPD user. Alternatively, the hardware specifications of any scope (any project, any space, or global hardware specifications) may be retrieved by Service Auth.

```sh
cpdctl environment hardware-specification list [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}] [--name NAME]
```

#### Command options

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--name` (string)
:   The name of the hardware specification. If specified, each of the hardware specification in the returned list will have the specified name.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The id of the project. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The id of the space. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl environment hardware-specification list \
    --space-id 82ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --project-id 92ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --name exampleString
```

Authorization rules for (1) and (2) follow those for `/v2/assets` for projects and spaces, respectively. Alternatively, the request is authorized for a valid authentication by Service Auth. :   Name of the hardware specification.

## • <a name="environment_package-extension_create">`environment package-extension create`</a>
Create a new package extension.

The new package extension is created in the given project or space, depending on whether project_id or space_id is provided. Authorization rules for package extensions follow those of `/v2/assets` for projects or spaces. For uploading the pip_zip or conda_yml, once you have created a package extension, the response also contains a pre-signed URL, which allows you to upload its contents. When the upload is complete, you MUST call
`POST /v2/package_extensions/{package_extension_guid}/upload_complete` to indicate the API that the package extension is usable. If the `/upload_complete` returns successfully, the package extension is usable, i.e., can be assigned to a software specification.

```sh
cpdctl environment package-extension create --name NAME --type TYPE [--description DESCRIPTION] [{--space-id SPACE-ID | --space SPACE-NAME}] [{--project-id PROJECT-ID | --project PROJECT-NAME}]
```

#### Command options

`--cpd-scope` (string)
:   CPD space or project scope, e.g. 'cpd://default-profile/spaces/7bccdda4-9752-4f37-868e-891de6c48135'

`--description` (string)
:   The description of the package extension. Can be any string.

`--name` (string)
:   The name of the package extension. Should be unique.

`--project` (string)
:   Project name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project-id'.

`--project-id` (string)
:   The id of the project in which to create the package extension. This option is mutually exclusive with '--project'.

`--space` (string)
:   Deployment space name. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space-id'.

`--space-id` (string)
:   The id of the space. This option is mutually exclusive with '--space'.

`--type` (string)
:   The type of the package extension.

##### Example

```sh
   cpdctl environment package-extension create \
    --name 'my-regex-parser v1.0.5' \
    --type pip_zip \
    --description 'a regex parser that I wrote' \
    --space-id 82ae0e27-9b11-4de9-a646-d46ca3c183d4 \
    --project-id 103d3fc4-2e46-4581-a23a-b4484e13519e
```
